title: أَمَّا الشَّرْطِيَّة
description: Learn about أَمَّا الشَّرْطِيَّة, the conditional particle that requires فَ in its response clause, as in أَمَّا زَيْدٌ فَذَهَبَ (As for Zayd, he left).

notes.title: What is أَمَّا الشَّرْطِيَّة?
content: أَمَّا is a conditional particle (حرف شرط وتفصيل) that introduces a topic and requires فَ in its response clause. It is translated as 'as for' or 'regarding' in English.
The structure أَمَّا... فَـ is used to divide and organize topics, emphasize a particular subject, or provide contrastive information. It is extremely common in both classical and modern Arabic.
keyPoints: Requires فَ (called فاء الجزاء) in the response
Very common in Quran and Arabic prose

examples.english: As for knowledge, it is beneficial

examples.arabic: أَمَّا بَعْدُ فَإِنَّ خَيْرَ الْكَلَامِ كَلَامُ اللهِ
examples.english: To proceed: the best speech is Allah's speech
As for the sky, it is clear

notes.title: The Obligatory فَ with أَمَّا
content: The فَ after أَمَّا is called فاء الجزاء (the response فَ) or الفاء الواقعة في جواب أَمَّا. It is obligatory and cannot be omitted in standard usage.
Sibawayhi explained that أَمَّا is derived from مَهْمَا يَكُنْ مِنْ شَيْءٍ (whatever the case may be), which is a conditional structure. This explains why it requires the فَ of condition response.
keyPoints: Called فاء الجزاء or الفاء الرابطة
Cannot be omitted in standard Arabic
أَمَّا = مَهْمَا يَكُنْ مِنْ شَيْءٍ (whatever the case)

examples.english: As for the orphan, do not oppress (Quran 93:9)
As for the petitioner, do not repel (Quran 93:10)
As for your Lord's blessing, proclaim it (Quran 93:11)
And as for your Lord's blessing, proclaim it

notes.title: Grammatical Parsing of أَمَّا Sentences
content: In أَمَّا زَيْدٌ فَكَرِيمٌ, the parsing is: أَمَّا (حرف شرط وتفصيل مبني), زَيْدٌ (مبتدأ مرفوع), فَـ (الفاء رابطة/واقعة في جواب أَمَّا), كَرِيمٌ (خبر المبتدأ مرفوع).
The noun after أَمَّا is typically مبتدأ (subject), and what comes after فَ is the خبر (predicate). The entire construction forms a جملة اسمية (nominal sentence) with conditional flavor.
keyPoints: أَمَّا: حرف شرط وتفصيل مبني لا محل له
The noun after أَمَّا is usually مبتدأ
What follows فَ is the خبر or جواب الشرط
The sentence is اسمية (nominal) or فعلية (verbal)

examples.english: الطُّلَّابُ: مبتدأ، نَجَحُوا: جملة فعلية خبر

notes.title: Quranic and Classical Usage
content: أَمَّا appears extensively in the Quran, often in pairs to present contrasting ideas. In Surah Al-Layl: فَأَمَّا مَنْ أَعْطَى وَاتَّقَى... وَأَمَّا مَنْ بَخِلَ وَاسْتَغْنَى (As for he who gives and fears... but as for he who withholds and thinks himself free of need).
The expression أَمَّا بَعْدُ (to proceed / furthermore) is used to transition from an introduction to the main content of a speech or letter. It is Sunnah in khutbahs.
keyPoints: Often used in pairs for contrast
أَمَّا بَعْدُ: classical phrase for transition
Sunnah to use أَمَّا بَعْدُ in sermons

examples.arabic: فَأَمَّا مَنْ أَعْطَى وَاتَّقَى وَصَدَّقَ بِالْحُسْنَى فَسَنُيَسِّرُهُ لِلْيُسْرَى
examples.english: As for he who gives and fears Allah and believes in the best - We will ease him toward ease (92:5-7)

examples.arabic: وَأَمَّا مَنْ بَخِلَ وَاسْتَغْنَى وَكَذَّبَ بِالْحُسْنَى فَسَنُيَسِّرُهُ لِلْعُسْرَى
examples.english: But as for he who withholds and considers himself free of need and denies the best - We will ease him toward difficulty (92:8-10)

examples.arabic: أَمَّا بَعْدُ، فَإِنَّ أَصْدَقَ الْحَدِيثِ كِتَابُ اللهِ
examples.english: To proceed: the most truthful speech is the Book of Allah
As for the ship, it belonged to poor people (18:79)
